crypto.name: Blocked1
crypto.desc:
doubledelete

The WOLPHV group (yes, this is an actual article) group encrypted our files, but then blocked us for some reason. I think they might have lost the key. Let's log into their accounts and find it...

crypto.name: Blocked2
crypto.desc:
doubledelete

We managed to log into doubledelete's email server. Hopefully this should give us some leads...

crypto.name: Limited 1
crypto.desc:
catgut6675

It's pretty easy to find random integers if you know the seed, but what if every second has a different seed?

crypto.name: Limited 2
crypto.desc:
catgut6675

I was AFK when the flag was being encrypted, can you help me get it back?

crypto.name: TagSeries1
crypto.desc:
retu2libc

Don't worry, the interns wrote this one.

crypto.name: TagSeries2
crypto.desc:
retu2libc

The interns have reworked it...

crypto.name: TagSeries3
crypto.desc:
retu2libc

Surely they got it right this time.

crypto.name: TwoTimePad
crypto.desc:
cogsworth64

One-time pads are perfectly information-theoretically secure, so I should be safe, right?

crypto.name: yORs Truly heart
crypto.desc:
shlswnt

I have encrypted some text but it seems I have lost the key! Can you find it?

forensic.name: Eternally Pwned Infiltration
forensic.desc:
dree_

I recently had my passwords and other sensitive data leaked, but I have no idea how. Can you figure out how the attacker got in to my PC?

forensic.name: Hidden Data
forensic.desc: WOLPHV sent me this file. Not sure what to comment about it

forensic.name: Log Analysis
forensic.desc:
dree_

Hi there incident responder. So we have this company that was breached sometime last week, but their SOC team only keeps HTTP request logs :( We took down all of our wolvsecsolutions websites as a precaution.

Maybe there's still a way to figure out what happened? Why did they click on a suspicious link? Somebody told me there's a flag on the link now?

misc.name: Befuddled1
misc.desc:
doubledelete

it seems yall enjoyed the befunge challenges, here's more

i've been doing a little too much code golf recently...

misc.name: Befuddled2
misc.desc:
doubledelete

ok, that one mighta been a little too easy >.<

misc.name: Befuddled3
misc.desc:
doubledelete

hope you're good at golf

misc.name: UnholyFile
misc.desc:
retu2libc

It's an unholy file cast out from a holy land.

Maybe try out UnholyEXE first.

pwn.name: DeepString
pwn.desc:
didkd

I had DeepThought running, but Wolphv reprogrammed it so that it now only performs string functions...

pwn.name: Game CET Match
pwn.desc: I wrote a tennis client with the bleeding-edge mitigations, that means it's unhackable, right?

pwn.name: babypwn
pwn.desc:
iqlusion

Just a little baby pwn.

pwn.name: byteOverflow.com
pwn.desc:
didkd

Wolphv deleted my web browser. Thankfully, I can still access my favorite website through the command line with this program I wrote.

pwn.name: netpeek
pwn.desc: Check out our new netpeek file preview utility. If a file is worth viewing, we'll let you take a peek.

pwn.name: shelleater
pwn.desc:
beanmite

go ahead, give me a shell >;)

rev.name: Assembled
rev.desc:
doubledelete

handwritten assembly to screw your decompiler in particular

rev.name: Game Graphics Debugging
rev.desc:
ravbug

I put a flag in this game, but I can't see it! Can you find it for me?

rev.name: Missing Resources
rev.desc:
ravbug

My flag is somewhere in this game, but I lost the source code and most of the resources! Can you retrieve it for me?

rev.name: Shredded
rev.desc:
cogsworth64

We encoded a flag, and to make sure that pesky interlopers couldn't reverse it, we shredded the encoding code.

Note: The encoder was written in C. The code is written with good style, but all indents have been removed.

rev.name: UnholyEXE
rev.desc:
retu2libc

I think I'm feeling a connection here...

Remember Terry zealously blessed the pcnet driver

rev.name: babyre
rev.desc:
iqlusion

Just a wee-little baby re challenge.

rev.name: befudged up
rev.desc:
doubledelete

people always talk about befunge being hard to compile but what about compiling to befunge

rev.name: collateral damage
rev.desc:
hcadam

You know the drill. Don't suffer too much collateral_damage

rev.name: doubledeletes revenge
rev.desc:
doubledelete

The notorious WOLPHV group has re-emerged and doubledelete is now ransoming us for our flags! Can you help us so we don't have to pay them?

rev.name: palworld
rev.desc:
hcadam

We have Palworld at home. Palworld at home:

rev.name: some flag is not an error
rev.desc:
doubledelete

Hope you enjoy error messages. Make the program compile.

It should be relatively obvious how to convert the structs into the flag.

Replace <> with {} before submitting; you should have something like

wctf<_t,_h,_e,__,_f,_l,_a,_g>::valid

=> wctf{the_flag}
